origin_of_ch_char_book: (è–, åœ£, sheng, holy, sage) reflects the ancient Chinese thoughts about the holy person (sage). This symbol is composed of a person whose position is low (äºº, ren, human) and on the top an ear (è€³, er, ear), and a mouth (å£, kou, mouse) next to them. It shows someone listening to what others are saying. In his book â€œChun Qiuâ€, Confucius emphasizes how important it is to listen well to others, especially the heavenly God. This is why Confucius who listened attentively is regarded as â€œHoly Manâ€ or â€œSageâ€. Confucius said that â€œAt age sixty, I heard and followed (the words from the Heavens).â€ In other words, he is confessing that it took him sixty years to hear Heavenâ€™s command.,(å¬, ting, hear) shows a mouth and an ear (è€³, er, ear). It is a scene of the loud sound, and listening to the sound. This character used to mean â€œto laugh with mouth openâ€ before. But now this symbol is used for â€œlisteningâ€ instead of the old symbol è½ (ting, hear) which is too complicated for a common word. (ç¬‘, xiao=Hsiao, laugh) Above are bamboo treeâ€™s leaves, and a person is laughing loudly with his neck bent backward .,In ancient China, people enjoyed music created on various instruments. (è², å£°, sheng, sound) is a character combination which shows a musical instrument (çŸ³, shi, stone) that is made by a flat stone, an ear (è€³, er, ear), a mouth which is singing , a bow to play the instrument, and a hand which is holding the bow. All together, it shows someone playing a stone instrument similar to the one shown below. Later the meaning of the word evolved to mean â€œsoundâ€.
humanum_full_description_en:
Inscriptions like ears. "Shuowen": "Ear, the main hearing, pictogram. All ears belong to the ear." The inscription " ear " is used as the original meaning. Bronze inscriptions are used as the names of people, such as Yaerqidding: "Aerchaqiding [é˜å°Š] Yi". Ear characters are mostly seen in early inscriptions, and are also used in clan emblem characters, as a mark of clan, such as ear [å½³å¤‚å¤§äº] Father Guigui. Ear is one of the radicals, and the word Cong Er is mostly related to hearing.

In the pre-Qin classics, " ear " is borrowed as a modal auxiliary word, which is located at the end of a sentence, expressing limit, decision, affirmation, or the pause or end of a sentence. "The Analects. "Yanghuo": "Yanzhiyan is also, the preface is the ear of drama."

Basic explanation of words
ear
Ä›r
The organ of hearing and balance sense (commonly known as "ear"): the back of the ear (b å•). earlobe. Ears and temples are rubbed together (m?). Ear points. Ears and eyes are clear. Ears and eyes.
Something like ears: fungus. Tremella.
Things on both sides like ears: the penthouse. Ding ears.
Heard: heard. Soft ears. Ershun (referring to the age of sixty, when you hear other people's words, you can know his subtle meaning, later referring to people who are sixty years old).
Auxiliary words in classical Chinese, nothing more: take it for granted.
Classical modal particles (roughly the same as "çŸ£"): "If a strong man is immortal, it is enough, and death is a great name."

ear
Chinese dictionary definition of words
[â‘ ] [Ä›r]
["Guangyun" and stop cut, top stop, day. ]
(1) Ears. Hearing and balance organs of humans and mammals.
(2) Like two ears lined up on both sides.
(3) Refers to those on both sides.
(4) Refers to food that is shaped like an ear.
(5) The sprouts of grain produced by rain.
(6) Heard; heard.
(7) Attach a whisper to the ear.
(8) Conjunctions. Indicates a turning point, which is equivalent to "and".
(9) Modal particles. Indicates a restricted tone, which is synonymous with "just" and "forget it".
(10) Modal particles. Indicates the pause and end of affirmative tone or sentence.
(11) Last name. Ming Hongxi has ears and Yuanming.

Meaning Mnemonic
The ear radical and ear kanji are the same in looks as well as meaning.
Study those radicals hard to make sure you know your kanji as well!
Reading Mnemonic
